cleaned_text: Ayurveda |This article is part of with historical roots in the Indian subcontinent. [[2]](#cite_note-HIML-intro-2) It is heavily practiced in India and Nepal, where around 80% of the population report using Ayurveda. [[3]](#cite_note-Dargan-3) [[4]](#cite_note-:1-4) [[5]](#cite_note-:3-5) The theory and practice of Ayurveda is [pseudoscientific](/wiki/Pseudoscientific). [[6]](#cite_note-kaufman-6) [[7]](#cite_note-oxpsych-7) [[8]](#cite_note-Quack-2011-8) Ayurveda therapies have varied and evolved over more than two millennia. [[2]](#cite_note-HIML-intro-2) Ayurvedic preparations are typically based on complex herbal compounds, minerals, and metal substances (perhaps under the influence of early Indian alchemy or [rasashastra](/wiki/Rasashastra)). Ancient Ayurveda texts also taught surgical techniques, including [rhinoplasty](/wiki/Rhinoplasty), [kidney stone extractions](/wiki/Lithotomy), sutures, and the extraction of foreign objects. [[11]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWujastyk2003a-11) [[12]](#cite_note-mukh-surg-12) The main classical Ayurveda texts begin with accounts of the transmission of medical knowledge from the gods to sages, and then to human physicians. [[13]](#cite_note-zysk-myth-13) Printed editions of the [Sushruta Samhita](/wiki/Sushruta_Samhita) (Sushruta's Compendium), frame the work as the teachings of [Dhanvantari](/wiki/Dhanvantari), [Hindu god](/wiki/Hindu_god) of Ayurveda, incarnated as King [Divodsa](/wiki/Divod%C4%81sa) of to a group of physicians, including Sushruta. [[14]](#cite_note-14) [[15]](#cite_note-britannica-15) The oldest manuscripts of the work, however, omit this frame, ascribing the work directly to King Divodsa. [[16]](#cite_note-16) Through well-understood processes of modernization and globalization, Ayurveda has been adapted for Western consumption, notably by [Baba Hari Dass](/wiki/Baba_Hari_Dass) in the 1970s and [Maharishi Ayurveda](/wiki/Maharishi_Ayurveda) in the 1980s. [[17]](#cite_note-:9-17) Historical evidence for Ayurvedic texts, terminology and concepts appears from the middle of the first millennium BCE onwards. [[18]](#cite_note-18) In Ayurveda texts, [Dosha](/wiki/Dosha) balance is emphasized, and suppressing natural urges is considered unhealthy and claimed to lead to illness. [[19]](#cite_note-WujastykXVIII-19) Ayurveda treatises describe three elemental doshas viz. vta, pitta and kapha, and state that balance ( [Skt.](/wiki/Skt.) smyatva) of the doshas results in health, while imbalance (viamatva) results in disease. Ayurveda treatises divide medicine into eight canonical components. Ayurveda practitioners had developed various medicinal preparations and surgical procedures from at least the beginning of the [common era](/wiki/Common_Era). [[20]](#cite_note-shar-hist-20) There is no good evidence that Ayurveda is effective to treat or cure cancer. [[10]](#cite_note-cruk-10) Some Ayurvedic preparations have been found to contain [lead](/wiki/Lead_poisoning), [mercury](/wiki/Mercury_poisoning), and [arsenic](/wiki/Arsenic_poisoning), [[9]](#cite_note-WebMD-9) substances known to be [harmful to humans](/wiki/Toxic_heavy_metal). A 2008 study found the three substances in close to 21% of U.S. and Indian-manufactured patent Ayurvedic medicines sold through the Internet. [[21]](#cite_note-Saper2008-21) The public health implications of such metallic contaminants in India are unknown. [[21]](#cite_note-Saper2008-21) Etymology The term yurveda ( of life and longevity". [[24]](#cite_note-GregoryFields-24) Eight components The earliest classical [Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit) works on Ayurveda describe medicine as being divided into eight components (Skt. aga). [[26]](#cite_note-26) [[27]](#cite_note-27) This characterization of the physician's art, medicine that has eight components" (Skt. cikitsym agy ), is first found in the Sanskrit epic the [Mahbhrata](/wiki/Mahabharata), c. 4th century BCE. [[28]](#cite_note-28) The components are: [[29]](#cite_note-29) [[24]](#cite_note-GregoryFields-24) [[30]](#cite_note-30) - Kyachikits: general medicine, medicine of the body - Kaumra-bhtya (Pediatrics): Discussions about prenatal and postnatal care of baby and mother; methods of conception; choosing the child's sex, intelligence, midwifery [[31]](#cite_note-31) - alyatantra: [surgical techniques](/wiki/History_of_surgery#India)and the extraction of foreign objects - hlkyatantra: treatment of ailments affecting openings or cavities in the upper body: ears, eyes, nose, mouth, etc. - Bhtavidy: pacification of possessing spirits, and the people whose minds are affected by such possession [Agadatantra](/wiki/Agada)/Vishagara-vairodh Tantra (Toxicology): includes epidemics; toxins in animals, vegetables and minerals; and keys for recognizing those anomalies and their antidotes - Rasyantantra: [rejuvenation](/wiki/Rejuvenation)and tonics for increasing lifespan, intellect and strength - Vjkaraatantra: [aphrodisiacs](/wiki/Aphrodisiacs); treatments for increasing the volume and viability of semen and sexual pleasure; infertility problems; and spiritual development (transmutation of sexual energy into spiritual energy) Principles and terminology The central theoretical ideas of Ayurveda show parallels with [Samkhya](/wiki/Samkhya) and [Vaisheshika](/wiki/Vaisheshika) philosophies, as well as with [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism) and [Jainism](/wiki/Jainism). [[32]](#cite_note-32) [[33]](#cite_note-33) Balance is emphasized, and suppressing natural urges is considered unhealthy and claimed to lead to illness. [[19]](#cite_note-WujastykXVIII-19) For example, to suppress sneezing is said to potentially give rise to shoulder pain. [[34]](#cite_note-34) However, people are also cautioned to stay within the limits of reasonable balance and measure when following nature's urges. [[19]](#cite_note-WujastykXVIII-19) For example, emphasis is placed on moderation of food intake, [[35]](#cite_note-Chopra75-35) sleep, and sexual intercourse. [[19]](#cite_note-WujastykXVIII-19) According to Ayurveda, the human body is composed of tissues ( [dhatus](/wiki/Dhatu_(Ayurveda))), waste (majja), and semen (shukra). Like the medicine of classical antiquity, the classic treatises of Ayurveda divided bodily substances into also twenty [gunas](/wiki/Guna) (qualities or characteristics) which are considered to be inherent in all matter. These are organized in the doshas or tridosha, are vata (air, which some modern authors equate with the nervous system), pitta (bile, fire, equated by some with enzymes), and kapha (phlegm, or earth and water, equated by some with mucus). Contemporary critics assert that doshas are not real, but are a fictional concept. [[39]](#cite_note-sn-39) The humours (doshas) may also affect mental health. Each dosha has particular attributes and roles within the body and mind; the natural predominance of one or more doshas thus explains a person's physical constitution (prakriti) and personality. [[36]](#cite_note-Mishra-36) [[40]](#cite_note-Payya-40) [[41]](#cite_note-41) Ayurvedic tradition holds that imbalance among the bodily and mental doshas is a major etiologic component of disease. One Ayurvedic view is that the doshas are balanced when they are equal to each other, while another view is that each human possesses a unique combination of the doshas which define this person's temperament and characteristics. In either case, it says that each person should modulate their behavior or environment to increase or decrease the doshas and maintain their natural state. Practitioners of Ayurveda must determine an individual's bodily and mental dosha makeup, as certain prakriti are said to predispose one to particular diseases. [[42]](#cite_note-mental-42) [[36]](#cite_note-Mishra-36) For example, a person who is thin, shy, excitable, has a pronounced [Adam's apple](/wiki/Adam%27s_apple), and enjoys of esoteric knowledge is likely vata prakriti and therefore more susceptible to conditions such as flatulence, stuttering, and rheumatism. [[36]](#cite_note-Mishra-36) [[43]](#cite_note-43) Deranged vata is also associated with certain mental disorders due to excited or excess vayu (gas), although the Ayurvedic text [Charaka Samhita](/wiki/Charaka_Samhita) also attributes "insanity" (unmada) to cold food and possession by the ghost a sinful Brahman ( [brahmarakshasa](/wiki/Brahmarakshasa)). "uncooked" or "undigested") is used to refer to the concept of anything that exists in a state of incomplete transformation. With regards to [oral hygiene](/wiki/Oral_hygiene), it is claimed to be a toxic byproduct generated by improper or incomplete [digestion](/wiki/Digestion). [[46]](#cite_note-46) [[47]](#cite_note-47) [[48]](#cite_note-48) The concept has no equivalent in [standard medicine](/wiki/Standard_medicine). In medieval taxonomies of the Sanskrit knowledge systems, Ayurveda is assigned a place as a subsidiary [Veda](/wiki/Veda) ( [upaveda](/wiki/Upaveda)). [[49]](#cite_note-49) Some medicinal plant names from the [Atharvaveda](/wiki/Atharvaveda) and other Vedas can be found in subsequent Ayurveda literature. [[50]](#cite_note-zysk-veda-50) Some other school of thoughts considers 'Ayurveda' as the ' [Fifth Veda](/wiki/Fifth_Veda)'. [[51]](#cite_note-51) The earliest recorded theoretical statements about the canonical models of disease in Ayurveda occur in the earliest [Buddhist Canon](/wiki/Buddhist_Canon). [[52]](#cite_note-zysk-asce-52) Practice Ayurvedic practitioners regard physical existence, mental existence, and personality as three separate elements of a whole person with each element being able to influence the others. [[53]](#cite_note-53) This [holistic](/wiki/Holism#Medicine) approach used during diagnosis and healing is a fundamental aspect of Ayurveda. Another part of Ayurvedic treatment says that there are channels (srotas) which transport fluids, and that the channels can be opened up by massage treatment using oils and [Swedana](/wiki/Swedana) (fomentation). Unhealthy, or blocked, channels are thought to cause disease. [[54]](#cite_note-WujastykXIX-XX-54) Diagnosis Ayurveda has eight ways to diagnose illness, called [Nadi](/wiki/Nadi_(yoga)) (pulse), Mootra (urine), [Mala](/wiki/Malas_(Ayurveda)) (stool), Aakruti (appearance). [[55]](#cite_note-55) Ayurvedic practitioners approach diagnosis by using the five senses. [[56]](#cite_note-Chopra79-56) For example, hearing is used to observe the condition of breathing and speech. [[37]](#cite_note-Underwood&Rhodes(2008)-37) The study of the lethal points or marman marma is of special importance. [[38]](#cite_note-Chopra76-38) Treatment and prevention Two of the eight branches of classical Ayurveda deal with surgery (alya-cikits and lkya-tantra), but contemporary Ayurveda tends to stress attaining vitality by building a healthy [metabolic system](/wiki/Metabolism) and maintaining good digestion and [excretion](/wiki/Excretion). [[38]](#cite_note-Chopra76-38) Ayurveda also focuses on exercise, [yoga](/wiki/Yoga), and [meditation](/wiki/Meditation). [[57]](#cite_note-encarta-ayurveda-57) One type of prescription is a [Sattvic diet](/wiki/Sattvic_diet). Ayurveda follows the concept of [Dinacharya](/wiki/Dinacharya), which says that natural cycles (waking, sleeping, working, meditation etc.) are important for health. Hygiene, including regular bathing, cleaning of teeth, [oil pulling](/wiki/Oil_pulling), [tongue scraping](/wiki/Tongue_scraping), skin care, and eye washing, is also a central practice. [[37]](#cite_note-Underwood&Rhodes(2008)-37) Substances used The vast majority (90%) of Ayurvedic remedies are plant based. [[58]](#cite_note-:7-58) Plant-based treatments in Ayurveda may be derived from roots, leaves, fruits, bark, or seeds; some examples of plant-based substances include [cardamom](/wiki/Cardamom) and [cinnamon](/wiki/Cinnamon). In the 19th century, William Dymock and co-authors summarized hundreds of plant-derived medicines along with the uses, microscopic structure, chemical composition, toxicology, prevalent myths and stories, and relation to commerce in [British India](/wiki/British_Raj). [[59]](#cite_note-59) [Triphala](/wiki/Triphala), an herbal formulation of three fruits, [Amalaki](/wiki/Amalaki), [Bibhitaki](/wiki/Bibhitaki), and [Haritaki](/wiki/Haritaki), is one of the most commonly (Tulsi) [[58]](#cite_note-:7-58) are also routinely used in Ayurveda. Animal products used in Ayurveda include milk, bones, and [gallstones](/wiki/Gallstone). [[64]](#cite_note-64) In addition, fats are prescribed both for consumption and for external use. Consumption of minerals, including [sulphur](/wiki/Sulphur), [arsenic](/wiki/Arsenic), lead, [copper sulfate](/wiki/Copper_sulfate) and gold, are also prescribed. [[37]](#cite_note-Underwood&Rhodes(2008)-37) The addition of minerals to herbal medicine is called [rasashastra](/wiki/Rasashastra). Ayurveda uses alcoholic beverages called Madya, [[65]](#cite_note-IJTNJAN07-65) which are said to adjust the doshas by increasing pitta and reducing vatta and kapha. [[65]](#cite_note-IJTNJAN07-65) Madya are classified by the raw material and fermentation process, and the categories include: sugar-based, fruit-based, cereal-based, cereal-based with herbs, fermentated with vinegar, and tonic wines. The intended outcomes can include causing purgation, improving digestion or taste, creating dryness, or loosening joints. Ayurvedic texts describe Madya as non-viscid and fast-acting, and say that it enters and cleans minute pores in the body. [[65]](#cite_note-IJTNJAN07-65) Purified [opium](/wiki/Opium) [[66]](#cite_note-ISHS1036-66) is used in eight Ayurvedic preparations [[67]](#cite_note-UNODC-67) and is said to balance the vata and kapha doshas and increase the pitta dosha. [[66]](#cite_note-ISHS1036-66) It is prescribed for diarrhea and dysentery, for increasing the sexual and muscular ability, and for affecting the brain. The sedative and pain-relieving properties of opium are considered in Ayurveda. The use of opium is found in the ancient Ayurvedic texts, and is first mentioned in the Sarngadhara Samhita (1300-1400 CE), a book on pharmacy used in [Rajasthan](/wiki/Rajasthan) in Western India, as an ingredient of an aphrodisiac to delay male ejaculation. [[68]](#cite_note-IJHS051981-68) It is possible that opium was brought to India along with or before [Muslim conquests](/wiki/Muslim_conquests_on_the_Indian_subcontinent). [[67]](#cite_note-UNODC-67) [[69]](#cite_note-Chopra80-69) The book Yoga Ratnakara (1700-1800 CE, unknown author), which is popular in [Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra), uses opium in a herbal-mineral composition prescribed for diarrhea. [[68]](#cite_note-IJHS051981-68) In the Bhaisajya Ratnavali, opium and [camphor](/wiki/Camphor) are used for acute gastroenteritis. In this drug, the respiratory depressant action of opium is counteracted by the respiratory stimulant property of camphor. [[68]](#cite_note-IJHS051981-68) Later books have included the narcotic property for use as analgesic pain reliever. [[68]](#cite_note-IJHS051981-68) [Cannabis indica](/wiki/Cannabis_indica) is also mentioned in the ancient Ayurveda books, and is first mentioned in the Sarngadhara Samhita as a treatment for diarrhea. [[68]](#cite_note-IJHS051981-68) In the Bhaisajya Ratnavali it is named as an ingredient in an aphrodisiac. [[68]](#cite_note-IJHS051981-68) Ayurveda says that both oil and tar can be used to stop bleeding, [[37]](#cite_note-Underwood&Rhodes(2008)-37) and that traumatic bleeding can be stopped by four different methods: [ligation](/wiki/Ligature_(medicine)) of the [blood vessel](/wiki/Blood_vessel), [cauterisation](/wiki/Cauterisation) by heat, use of preparations to facilitate [clotting](/wiki/Clotting), and use of preparations to [constrict](/wiki/Vasoconstriction) the blood vessels. Massage with oil is commonly prescribed by Ayurvedic practitioners. [[70]](#cite_note-70) Oils are used in a number of ways, including regular consumption, anointing, smearing, head massage, application to affected areas, [[71]](#cite_note-WujastykXX-71)[ [failed verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability)] and oil pulling. Liquids may also be poured on the patient's forehead, a technique called shirodhara. [[72]](#cite_note-Cacho_Lum-72) Panchakarma According to Ayurveda, panchakarma are techniques to [eliminate toxic elements from the body](/wiki/Detoxification_(alternative_medicine)). [[73]](#cite_note-73) Panchakarma refers to five actions, which are meant to be performed in a designated sequence with the stated aim of restoring balance in the body through a process of purgation. [[74]](#cite_note-Sujatha_UniversalGlobal_2020-74) Current status Ayurveda is widely practiced in India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, and Nepal [[75]](#cite_note-who01-75) where public institutions offer formal study in the form of a [Bachelor of Ayurvedic Medicine and Surgery](/wiki/Bachelor_of_Ayurvedic_Medicine_and_Surgery) (BAMS) degree. In certain parts of the world, the legal standing of practitioners is equivalent to that of conventional medicine. [[75]](#cite_note-who01-75) Several scholars have described the contemporary Indian application of Ayurvedic practice as being "biomedicalized" relative to the more "spiritualized" emphasis to practice found in variants in the West. [[76]](#cite_note-london_\2-76) [[74]](#cite_note-Sujatha_UniversalGlobal_2020-74) Exposure to European developments in medicine from the nineteenth century onwards, through [European colonization of India](/wiki/European_colonization_of_India) and the subsequent institutionalized support for European forms of medicine amongst European heritage settlers in India [[77]](#cite_note-77) were challenging to Ayurveda, with the entire [epistemology](/wiki/Epistemology) called into question. From the twentieth century, Ayurveda became politically, conceptually, and commercially dominated by modern [biomedicine](/wiki/Biomedicine), resulting in "Modern Ayurveda" and "Global Ayurveda". [[22]](#cite_note-MaasCambridge_2018-22) Modern Ayurveda is geographically located in the [Indian subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_subcontinent) and tends towards secularization through minimization of the magic and mythic aspects of Ayurveda. [[22]](#cite_note-MaasCambridge_2018-22) [[23]](#cite_note-Smith+Wujastyk-23) Global Ayurveda encompasses multiple forms of practice that developed through dispersal to a wide geographical area outside of India. [[22]](#cite_note-MaasCambridge_2018-22) Smith and Wujastyk further delineate that Global Ayurveda includes those primarily interested in the Ayurveda [pharmacopeia](/wiki/Pharmacopoeia), and also the practitioners of [New Age](/wiki/New_Age) Ayurveda (which may link Ayurveda to yoga and Indian spirituality and/or emphasize preventative practice, mind body medicine, or [Maharishi Ayurveda](/wiki/Maharishi_Ayurveda)). [[23]](#cite_note-Smith+Wujastyk-23) Since the 1980s, Ayurveda has also become the subject of interdisciplinary studies in [ethnomedicine](/wiki/Ethnomedicine) which seeks to integrate the biomedical sciences and humanities to improve the pharmacopeia of Ayurveda. [[23]](#cite_note-Smith+Wujastyk-23) According to Industry Research, the global Ayurveda market was worth US$4.5 billion in 2017. [[78]](#cite_note-market-78) The Indian subcontinent India It was reported in 2008 [[3]](#cite_note-Dargan-3) and again in 2018 [[79]](#cite_note-:0-79) that 80 percent of people in India used Ayurveda exclusively or combined with conventional Western medicine. [[3]](#cite_note-Dargan-3) [[79]](#cite_note-:0-79) A 2014 national health survey found that, in general, forms of the Indian System of Medicine or [AYUSH](/wiki/AYUSH) (Ayurveda, Yoga and naturopathy, Unani, Sidha, and Homeopathy) were used by about 3.5% of patients who were seeking outpatient care over a two-week reference period. [[80]](#cite_note-80) In 1970, the [Parliament of India](/wiki/Parliament_of_India) passed the Indian Medical Central Council Act which aimed to standardise qualifications for Ayurveda practitioners and provide accredited institutions for its study and research. [[81]](#cite_note-WujastykXXII-81) In 1971, the [Central Council of Indian Medicine](/wiki/Central_Council_of_Indian_Medicine) (CCIM) was established under the Department of Ayurveda, Yoga and Naturopathy, Unani, [Siddha medicine](/wiki/Siddha_medicine) and Homoeopathy (AYUSH), [Ministry of Health and Family Welfare](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_and_Family_Welfare), to monitor higher education in Ayurveda in India. [[82]](#cite_note-82) The Indian government supports research and teaching in Ayurveda through many channels at both the national and state levels, and helps institutionalise traditional medicine so that it can be studied in major towns and cities. [[83]](#cite_note-WujastykXVI-83) The state-sponsored Central Council for Research in Ayurvedic Sciences (CCRAS) is designed to do research on Ayurveda. [[84]](#cite_note-84) Many clinics in urban and rural areas are run by professionals who qualify from these institutes. [[81]](#cite_note-WujastykXXII-81) As of 2013 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ayurveda&action=edit), India had over 180 training centers that offered degrees in traditional Ayurvedic medicine. [[57]](#cite_note-encarta-ayurveda-57) To fight [biopiracy](/wiki/Biopiracy) and unethical patents, the [government of India](/wiki/Government_of_India) set up the [Traditional Knowledge Digital Library](/wiki/Traditional_Knowledge_Digital_Library) in 2001 to serve as a repository for formulations from systems of Indian medicine, such as Ayurveda, [Unani](/wiki/Unani) and Siddha medicine. [[85]](#cite_note-85) [[86]](#cite_note-pt-86) The formulations come from over 100 traditional Ayurveda books. [[87]](#cite_note-87) An [Indian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Indian_Academy_of_Sciences) document quoting a 2003-04 report states that India had 432,625 registered medical practitioners, 13,925 dispensaries, 2,253 hospitals and a bed strength of 43,803. 209 undergraduate teaching institutions and 16 postgraduate institutions. [[88]](#cite_note-IAS-20150613-88) In 2012, it was reported that insurance companies covered expenses for Ayurvedic treatments in case of conditions such as spinal cord disorders, bone disorder, arthritis and cancer. Such claims constituted 5-10 percent of the country's health insurance claims. [[89]](#cite_note-Hindu-20120328-89) [Maharashtra Andhashraddha Nirmoolan Samiti](/wiki/Maharashtra_Andhashraddha_Nirmoolan_Samiti), an organisation dedicated to in India](/wiki/Superstition_in_India), considers Ayurveda to be pseudoscience. [[8]](#cite_note-Quack-2011-8) On 9 November 2014, India formed the [Ministry of AYUSH](/wiki/Ministry_of_AYUSH). [[90]](#cite_note-90) [[91]](#cite_note-91) National Ayurveda Day is also observed in India on the birth of [Dhanvantari](/wiki/Dhanvantari) that is [Dhanteras](/wiki/Dhanteras). [[92]](#cite_note-92) In 2016, the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) (WHO) published a report titled "The Health Workforce in India" which found that 31 percent of those who claimed to be doctors in India in 2001 were educated only up to the secondary school level and 57 percent went without any medical qualification. [[93]](#cite_note-:6-93) The WHO study found that the situation was worse in rural India with only 18.8 percent of doctors holding a medical qualification. [[93]](#cite_note-:6-93) Overall, the study revealed that nationally the density of all doctors (mainstream, ayurvedic, homeopathic and unani) was 8 doctors per 10,000 people compared to 13 per 10,000 people in China. [[93]](#cite_note-:6-93) [[94]](#cite_note-94) Nepal About 75% to 80% of the population of Nepal use Ayurveda. [[4]](#cite_note-:1-4) [[5]](#cite_note-:3-5) As of 2009, Ayurveda was considered to be the most common and popular form of medicine in Nepal. [[95]](#cite_note-95) Sri Lanka The Sri Lankan tradition of Ayurveda is similar to the Indian tradition. Practitioners of Ayurveda in Sri Lanka refer to Sanskrit texts which are common to both countries. However, they do differ in some aspects, particularly in the herbs used. In 1980, the Sri Lankan government established a [Ministry of Indigenous Medicine](/wiki/Ministry_of_Indigenous_Medicine) to revive and regulate Ayurveda. [[96]](#cite_note-96) The [Institute of Indigenous Medicine](/wiki/Institute_of_Indigenous_Medicine) (affiliated to the [University of Colombo](/wiki/University_of_Colombo)) offers undergraduate, postgraduate, and MD degrees in Ayurveda Medicine and Surgery, and similar degrees in unani medicine. [[97]](#cite_note-97) In 2010, the public system had 62 Ayurvedic hospitals and 208 central dispensaries, which served about 3 million people (about 11% of Sri Lanka's population). There are an estimated 20,000 registered practitioners of Ayurveda in Sri Lanka. [[98]](#cite_note-98) [[99]](#cite_note-99) According to the [Mahavamsa](/wiki/Mahavamsa), an ancient chronicle of [Sinhalese](/wiki/Sinhalese_people) royalty from the sixth century CE, King [Pandukabhaya](/wiki/Pandukabhaya) (reigned 437 BCE to 367 BCE) had lying-in-homes and Ayurvedic hospitals (Sivikasotthi-Sala) built in various parts of the country. This is the earliest documented evidence available of institutions dedicated specifically to the care of the sick anywhere in the world. [[100]](#cite_note-100) [[101]](#cite_note-101) The hospital at [Mihintale](/wiki/Mihintale) is the oldest in the world. [[102]](#cite_note-102) Outside the Indian subcontinent Ayurveda is a system of traditional medicine developed during antiquity and the medieval period, and as such is comparable to pre-modern [Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine) and [European systems of medicine](/wiki/Medieval_medicine_of_Western_Europe). In the 1960s, Ayurveda began to be advertised as [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) in the Western world. Due to different laws and medical regulations around the globe, the expanding practice and commercialisation of Ayurveda raised ethical and legal issues. [[103]](#cite_note-:10-103) Through well-understood processes of modernization and globalization, Ayurveda was adapted for Western consumption, notably by Baba Hari Dass in the 1970s and by Maharishi Ayurveda in the 1980s. [[17]](#cite_note-:9-17) In some cases, this involved active fraud on the part of proponents of Ayurveda in an attempt to falsely represent the system as equal to the standards of modern [medical research](/wiki/Medical_research). [[103]](#cite_note-:10-103) [[104]](#cite_note-104) [[105]](#cite_note-105) United States [Baba Hari Dass](/wiki/Baba_Hari_Dass) was an early proponent who helped bring Ayurveda to the United States in the early 1970s. His teachings led to the establishment of the Mount Madonna Institute. [[106]](#cite_note-106) He invited several notable Ayurvedic teachers, including Vasant Lad, Sarita Shrestha, and [Ram Harsh The Ayurvedic practitioner Michael Tierra wrote that the "history of Ayurveda in North America will always owe a debt to the selfless contributions of Baba Hari Dass." [[107]](#cite_note-107) In the United States, the practice of Ayurveda is not licensed or regulated by any state. The [National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health](/wiki/National_Center_for_Complementary_and_Integrative_Health) (NCCIH) stated that "Few well-designed clinical trials and systematic research reviews suggest that Ayurvedic approaches are effective". The NCCIH warned against the issue of heavy metal poisoning, and emphasised the use of conventional health providers first. [[108]](#cite_note-:5-108) As of 2018, the NCCIH reported that 240,000 Americans were using Ayurvedic medicine. [[108]](#cite_note-:5-108) Europe The first Ayurvedic clinic in Switzerland was opened in 1987 by [Maharishi Mahesh Yogi](/wiki/Maharishi_Mahesh_Yogi). [[109]](#cite_note-109) In 2015, the government of Switzerland introduced a federally recognized diploma in Ayurveda. [[110]](#cite_note-:8-110) Classification and efficacy Ayurvedic medicine is considered [pseudoscientific](/wiki/Pseudoscientific) because its premises are not based on science. [[7]](#cite_note-oxpsych-7) [[6]](#cite_note-kaufman-6) Both the lack of scientific soundness in the theoretical foundations of Ayurveda and the quality of research have been criticized. [[7]](#cite_note-oxpsych-7) [[111]](#cite_note-Sujatha2011-111) [[112]](#cite_note-Manohar2013-112) [[113]](#cite_note-Bausell-113) Although laboratory experiments suggest that some herbs and substances in Ayurveda might be developed into effective treatments, there is no evidence that any are effective in themselves. [[114]](#cite_note-ACS2011-114) [[115]](#cite_note-115) There is no good evidence that Ayurvedic medicine is effective to treat or cure cancer in people. [[10]](#cite_note-cruk-10) Although Ayurveda may help "improve quality of life" and [Cancer Research UK](/wiki/Cancer_Research_UK) also acknowledges that "researchers have found that some Ayurvedic treatments can help relieve cancer symptoms," the organization warns that some Ayurvedic drugs contain toxic substances or may [interact](/wiki/Drug_interaction) with legitimate cancer drugs in a harmful way. [[10]](#cite_note-cruk-10) Ethnologist [Johannes Quack](/wiki/Johannes_Quack) writes that although the rationalist Andhashraddha Nirmoolan Samiti officially labels Ayurveda a pseudoscience akin to [astrology](/wiki/Astrology), these practices are in fact embraced by many of the movement's members. [[8]](#cite_note-Quack-2011-8) A review of the use of Ayurveda for [cardiovascular disease](/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease) concluded that the evidence is not convincing for the use of any Ayurvedic herbal treatment for heart disease or hypertension, but that many herbs used by Ayurvedic practitioners could be appropriate for further research. [[116]](#cite_note-Mamtani2005-116) Research In India, research in Ayurveda is undertaken by the Ministry of AYUSH through a national network of research institutes. [[117]](#cite_note-ccras-117) In Nepal, the National Ayurvedic Training and Research Centre (NATRC) researches medicinal herbs in the country. [[118]](#cite_note-118) In Sri Lanka, the [Ministry of Health, Nutrition and Indigenous Medicine](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health,_Nutrition_and_Indigenous_Medicine) looks after the research in Ayurveda through various national research institutes. [[119]](#cite_note-119) Use of toxic metals Rasashastra, the practice of adding metals, minerals or gems to herbal preparations, may include [toxic heavy metals](/wiki/Toxic_heavy_metal) such as lead, [mercury](/wiki/Mercury_(element)) and arsenic. [[21]](#cite_note-Saper2008-21) The public health implications of metals in rasashastra in India is unknown. [[21]](#cite_note-Saper2008-21) Adverse reactions to herbs are described in traditional Ayurvedic texts, but practitioners are reluctant to admit that herbs could be toxic and that reliable information on herbal toxicity is not readily available. [[142]](#cite_note-142) [[143]](#cite_note-143) Main texts Many ancient works on Ayurvedic medicine are lost to posterity, [[144]](#cite_note-144) but manuscripts of three principal early texts on Ayurveda have survived to the present day. These works are the Charaka Samhita, the [Sushruta Samhita](/wiki/Sushruta_Samhita) and the [Bhela Samhita](/wiki/Bhela_Samhita). The dating of these works is historically complicated since they each internally present themselves as composite works compiled by several editors. All past scholarship on their dating has been evaluated by Meulenbeld in volumes IA and IB of his History of Indian Medical Literature. [[2]](#cite_note-HIML-intro-2) After considering the evidence and arguments concerning the Surutasahit, Meulenbeld stated (IA, 348), The Surutasahit is most probably the work of an unknown author who drew much of the material he incorporated in his treatise from a multiplicity of earlier sources from various periods. This may explain that many scholars yield to the temptation to recognize a number of distinct layers and, consequently, try to identify elements belonging to them. As we have seen, the identification of features thought to belong to a particular stratum is in many cases determined by preconceived ideas on the age of the strata and their supposed authors. The dating of this work to 600 BCE was first proposed by Hoernle over a century ago, [[145]](#cite_note-145) but has long since been overturned by subsequent historical research. The current consensus amongst medical historians of South Asia is that the Surutasahit was compiled over a period of time starting with a kernel of medical ideas from the century or two BCE and then being revised by several hands into its present form by about 500 CE. [[2]](#cite_note-HIML-intro-2) [[20]](#cite_note-shar-hist-20) The view that the text was updated by the Buddhist scholar [Nagarjuna](/wiki/Nagarjuna) in the 2nd century CE [[146]](#cite_note-146) has been disproved, although the last chapter of the work, the Uttaratantra, was added by an unknown later author before 500 CE. [[2]](#cite_note-HIML-intro-2) Similar arguments apply to the Charaka Samhita, written [Charaka](/wiki/Charaka), and the Bhela Samhita, attributed to [Atreya](/wiki/Atreya) Punarvasu, that are also dated to the 6th century BCE by non-specialist scholars [[147]](#cite_note-147) [[148]](#cite_note-148) [[149]](#cite_note-149) but are in fact, in their present form, datable to a period between the second and fifth centuries CE.
